trial_identification.studytitle: Does cabergoline improve cognition and attention more than placebo in healthy volunteers and what does this tell us about mechanisms of attention?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial comparing the effects of cabergoline vs placebo on executive control in healthy male volunteers

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour
Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

interventions.interventions: A single dose of cabergoline (oral capsule containing 1.25mg) (1-2 week washout period between conditions)
interventions.comparator: A single dose of an identical looking placebo capsule (1-2 week washout period between conditions)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Response inhibition measured using the Stop Signal Task
Error awareness using the Error Awareness Task (EAT)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Spatial attention measured with two tasks, the Attention-Competition Task and the Grey-Scales Task

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Current psychiatric or neurological illness Current use of psychotropic medication CUrrent substance use or dependence Medical illness that is a contraindication for cabergoline use

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: The Queensland Brain Institute Building #79, Upland Rd The University of Queensland St Lucia QLD 4072

fundingsource.fundingaddress: The Queensland Brain Institute Building #79, Upland Rd The University of Queensland St Lucia QLD 4072

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Cognitive control and spatial attention are skills that allows us to interpret and act in our environment. Although these skills are important, little is understood about the neurochemical processes that are important to cognitive control and spatial attention. This study will allow us to assess the importance of different brain chemicals in contributing to spatial attention and cognitive function.
